item.description:
„Äê

#‚Äã538 ‚Äî January 15, 2025

Unsub¬†¬†|¬†¬†Web¬†Version

Go Weekly

An Interactive Tour of Go 1.24 ‚Äî A list of all the significant new 1.24 features. Each is accompanied by interactive, runnable examples so you can see generic type aliases in action, make (and clean up) weak pointers, play with file access, and see benchmarks for the new faster map¬†implementation. Go 1.24 is expected to land in the next month or two, with RC2 likely later this¬†week.

Anton Zhiyanov

üí° If you've not experienced Anton's Go tours before, you might also enjoy the Go 1.23 interactive¬†tour.

The First Newsletter Dedicated to Product Engineers ‚Äî The fastest growing startups increasingly rely on product engineers. They can both figure out what to build and actually build it. Product for Engineers is dedicated to sharing the skills and strategies needed to succeed in this¬†role.

PostHog sponsor

if got, want: A Simple Way to Write Better Go Tests ‚Äî ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs an excellent Go testing pattern that too few people know. I can teach it to you in 30 seconds‚Äù is quite the pitch. The trick is using both assignments and a comparison on a single if line to make a test easier to read ‚Äî¬†it‚Äôs even used in the standard¬†library.

Michael Lynch

Gophers Pack: A Collection of Gopher Pictures and Design¬†Elements ‚Äî If you want some handy Go gopher themed images to use for a project, blog post, or presentation, this myriad of cute CC0 (public domainish) elements could be a big help. We use them a lot in this newsletter and Maria has recently added a variety of winter themed¬†options.

Maria Letta

A Practical Example of Dependency Inversion using Plugins ‚Äî An example of using Clean Architecture principles with Go‚Äôs plugin package to create an app that‚Äôs adaptable and extendable without modifying the core source¬†code.

Christian Ekrem

Realizing Why Go Reflection Restricts What Struct Fields Can Be Modified ‚Äî Private (unexported) fields can‚Äôt be modified, even when using reflection. When looking at this through Rust-colored glasses, it makes more¬†sense.

Chris Siebenmann

üìÑ How HTTP/2 Works and How to Enable It in Go ‚Äì One of Phuong‚Äôs typically thorough¬†explanations. Phuong Le

üìÑ Designing a Distributed Circuit Breaker for Disabling Webhook Endpoints ‚Äì If you‚Äôre consuming a lot of third-party APIs, this could help keep your queues from¬†clogging. Raymond Tukpe (Core Gateway)

üì∫ The Creator of Ghostty Talks Zig over Go ‚Äì Controversial. Mitchell Hashimoto (of HashiCorp fame) has recently built Ghostty, a fast new terminal emulator, in Zig. But why not¬†Go? ThePrimeTime

üì∫ Implementing a Random Art Generation Algorithm ‚Äì A thorough walkthrough of a way to generate curious graphical¬†elements. package main

üìÑ Making 'Beautiful' API Keys ‚Äì Making auth tokens/keys more attractive probably shouldn‚Äôt be a priority, but if you want/need to, uuidkey may be for¬†you. Jack Spirou (AgentStation)

üìÑ Modifying Private Variables of a Struct with unsafe and reflect ‚Äì Remember it‚Äôs called unsafe for a¬†reason... Darshan N A

üìÑ Scaling LLMs with Go: How We Serve Millions of LLM Requests John Wang (Assembled)

üìÑ We Removed 335 LOC with One Go Package ‚Äì Going from generating a huge number of ffmpeg directives to a cloud-based audio transformation¬†approach. Poxate

üìÑ How rqlite, a Go-Powered SQLite-Based Database, is Tested Philip O'Toole

üõ† Code & Tools

go-mail v0.6: A Library for Sending Emails ‚Äî If you‚Äôve got email to send, go-mail can do the job. v0.6 adds support for S/IME signing, SMTP auth auto-discovery, Unix domain socket support, and a ‚Äòquick send‚Äô feature.

Winni Neessen et al.

ebpf-go 0.17: A Way to Work with eBPF from Go ‚Äî A pure Go library to read, modify and load eBPF programs for use directly by the Linux kernel (eBPF is a neat technology worth exploring if you‚Äôre not familiar with it yet). The new 0.17 release requires Go 1.22+ and introduces a new API to work with global¬†variables.

Beckers et al.

go-haystack: Track Personal Devices via Apple's 'Find My' Network ‚Äî An interesting way to track personal Bluetooth devices via Apple‚Äôs massive ‚ÄúFind My‚Äù network by way of TinyGo and a little extra¬†hardware.

Ron Evans

  • GoCV 0.40 ‚Äì The Go bindings for OpenCV 4 add support for OpenCV¬†4.11.0.

  • pgxmock 4.4 ‚Äì Mock driver to test Postgres interactions in¬†Go.

  • Cloudflare Go 4.0 ‚Äì Official library for the Cloudflare¬†API.

  • FrankenPHP 1.4 ‚Äì Modern Go-powered PHP app¬†server.

item.title: „ÄêThe latest Go dev survey results„ÄëÊúÄÊñ∞ÁöÑ Go ÂºÄÂèëËÄÖË∞ÉÊü•ÁªìÊûú
item.description:
„Äê

#‚Äã537 ‚Äî January 8, 2025

Unsub¬†¬†|¬†¬†Web¬†Version

Happy New Year to all. In case you missed our note prior to the Christmas break, Go Weekly is now published on Wednesdays ‚Äì we were missing too many high profile items that were landing late on Tuesdays, seemingly a common day for Go releases. Fingers crossed this helps us be even more timely!¬†ü§û
__
Peter Cooper and the Cooperpress team

Go Weekly

Go Developer Survey 2024 H2 Results ‚Äî The results of the latest Go community survey are out. Over 4000 responses were analyzed with developers largely being satisfied with Go‚Äôs direction, but finding maintaining consistent coding standards to be the biggest challenge. Linux and macOS lead the way with OS choice, VS Code and GoLand for IDEs, and AWS when it comes to clouds. We also get some interesting stats on the level of LLM use by Go¬†developers.

Alice Merrick

Master the Fullstack ‚Äî Expand your abilities to the server with this comprehensive learning path. You'll learn how to create APIs, build containers, deploy code, set up servers, and much¬†more.

Frontend Masters sponsor

How I Program with LLMs ‚Äî The co-founder of Tailscale shares his thoughts on modern approaches to writing Go code with numerous LLM-powered techniques and shares off a new LLM-powered ‚ÄòGo playground‚Äô he‚Äôs working¬†on.

David Crawshaw

IN BRIEF:

  • üéß We're sad to hear that the Go Time podcast is bowing out with its latest episode reflecting on eight years and 340 episodes of shows. However, Fallthrough is a new Go podcast that picks up Go Time's torch.

  • üá¨üáß If you want to attend this year's GopherCon UK, you can now save the date: it's in London on August 13-15. No rush, though, its CFP doesn't even open till¬†March.

  • üì∫ A variety of talks from GopherCon 2024 (which took place in July) have begun to land on YouTube, including ‚ñ∂Ô∏è a look at extending the Go compiler, ‚ñ∂Ô∏è building a firewall with Go, and ‚ñ∂Ô∏è code instrumentation techniques in high performance trading systems.

  • üá∫üá∏ On the topic of GopherCon, GopherCon 2025 takes place this August 26-28 in New York¬†City.

  • Juho Fors√©n reflects on a year of security fixes in Go.

Rust vs Go in 2025 ‚Äî An updated look at a topic that John often covers but with the same conclusion as ever: it‚Äôs worth knowing both¬†languages.

John Arundel

Build Go Apps using Project IDX and the Gemini API ‚Äî IDX is a Google-developed AI-assisted online workspace for full-stack app development. Here‚Äôs the bare basics of getting started with it for Go¬†work.

Mueller and Saba (Google)

Pixel Federation Swaps MSK for WarpStream, Saves 83% on Kafka Costs ‚Äî By swapping AWS MSK for WarpStream, Pixel Federation drastically reduced Kafka costs and eliminated complex VPC¬†peering.

WarpStream sponsor

üì∫ Why CGO is Dangerous ‚Äì A short, engaging and relatively high-level critique of¬†CGO. Rachel Lettuce

üìÑ Go Union Type Proposals Should Start with Their Objectives ‚Äì There have been a few proposals to add union types to Go, but Chris thinks they focus more on semantics than¬†objectives. Chris Siebenmann

üìÑ Go is a Well-Designed Language, Actually Matt Hall

üìÑ Why Go Should Sometimes Be a No-Go ‚Äì By way of contrast, this developer simply doesn‚Äôt find Go fun enough, yet.. is switching back to¬†Java..! Brain Baking

üìÑ Docker on macOS is Still Slow? ‚Äì A handy comparison of the performance of different¬†approaches. Paolo Mainardi

üìÑ Writing and Testing a Paginated API Iterator in Go Thibaut Rousseau

üìÑ Write Your Own json.Unmarshal TinyBirdPerson

üõ† Code & Tools

betteralign 0.6: Make Your Programs Use Less Memory.. Maybe ‚Äî A tool to detect structs that could use less memory if their fields were organized differently. It‚Äôs a fork of Go‚Äôs fieldalignment tool that skips generated or test files, skips specially marked structs or those with anonymous fields, doesn‚Äôt drop comments, and similar DX¬†enhancements.

Dinko Korunic

Fuego: A Nest-Inspired API/Web Framework for Go ‚Äî ‚ÄúThe only Go framework generating OpenAPI documentation from code. Inspired by Nest, built for Go developers.‚Äù Here‚Äôs a hello world example along with full docs. The latest version (0.17) adds (initial) Gin router¬†support.

Fuego, Inc.

templ: A Way to Build HTML with Go ‚Äî Create components that render fragments of HTML and compose them to create screens, pages, documents, and apps. GitHub¬†repo.

Adrian Hesketh

  • Mockery 3.0 Alpha ‚Äì Creates mock implementations of interfaces.

  • Caddy 2.9 ‚Äì Powerful Go-powered HTTP/1-2-3 server with automatic¬†HTTPS.

  • Pebble 2.0 ‚Äì RocksDB/LevelDB inspired key-value database in Go. Used by CockroachDB under the¬†hood.

  • River 0.15 ‚Äì Fast and reliable Postgres-powered background jobs for¬†Go.

  • go-github v68.0 ‚Äì GitHub v3 API client¬†library.

  • GoBGP 3.33 ‚Äì BGP implementation in¬†Go.

üì∞¬†Classifieds

üîπ Sell to enterprise with a few lines of code with WorkOS ‚Äî the modern, flexible identity platform for B2B SaaS. Integrate SSO, SCIM and FGA in minutes, not¬†months.

üêò Postgres user? Check out our sister newsletter, Postgres Weekly which starts its 2025 run of issues tomorrow.

üéÅ And one for fun..

Memos: A Privacy-First Go-Powered Note Taking App ‚Äî A complete, MIT-licensed note taking webapp that you can self host and which continues to see frequent updates. It uses Echo as a framework and stores its data in a SQLite file. GitHub¬†repo.

item.title: „ÄêWhat's missing from Go's generics?„ÄëGo ÁöÑÊ≥õÂûãÁº∫Â∞ë‰ªÄ‰πàÔºü
item.description:
„Äê

#‚Äã535 ‚Äî December 10, 2024

Unsub¬†¬†|¬†¬†Web¬†Version

Go Weekly

üïí¬†Coming in Go 1.24: An Experiment for Time and Concurrency¬†Testing ‚Äî A look at another feature coming to Go 1.24 early next year. This time it‚Äôs the experimental testing/synctest package which opens up some added opportunities for testing code involving time or concurrency: ‚ÄúIt seems that testing/synctest will significantly improve testing code that involves time or concurrency. At work, I‚Äôve already tried it on some flaky tests like the ones above and it‚Äôs¬†helped.‚Äù

Dan Peterson

What's Missing from Go's Generics? ‚Äî Follow-up to an article we recently linked that posited that Go‚Äôs generics are ‚Äòincomplete‚Äô which spurred some lively discussion. Here, Nick responds to that discussion with specific features and how Go may or may not benefit from their¬†inclusion.

Nick Tobey (DoltHub)

Master the Basics of Go ‚Äî Join Maximiliano Firtman for this detailed video course covering the fundamentals of all things Go. You'll gain a thorough understanding of structures, goroutines, channels, async API calls, and much much¬†more.

Frontend Masters sponsor

IN BRIEF:

  • Mostly noteworthy for its nice sounding version number, Go 1.23.4 has been released.

  • ü§ñ An interesting result in Cloudflare's 2024 year in review: Go has overtaken Node.js as the most common language they see being used to power 'API clients'/automated¬†requests.

  • Microsoft has released new versions of its custom Go builds covering Go 1.23.4 and 1.22.10. (You'd use these for FIPS compliance in the MS ecosystem.)

  • ü§ñ If you're into working with LLMs and AI from Go, /r/LLMGophers is a new sub-Reddit you might want to help¬†populate.

  • Simon Willison tries to figure out what the absolute simplest possible Hugo-powered site would¬†be.

Templ vs Gomponents vs html/template ‚Äî A comparison of three view related libraries for Go, including old favorite html/template (which, perhaps unfairly, gets a one star¬†rating).

Ewen Quimerc‚Äôh

üìÑ Building BLE Applications with BleuIO and Go ‚Äì BLE meaning Bluetooth Low Energy, in this case. They have a device they‚Äôre trying to sell, but it‚Äôs interesting to get a basic look at the¬†idea. BleuIO

üìÑ Data Structures as Jigs for Programmers (Go Edition) Daniel Lemire

üìÑ Mitigating SSRF Vulnerabilities in Go Liran Tal (Snyk)

üìÑ Disable Slog Messages in Go Tests Ben E. C. Boyter

üõ† Code & Tools

Soft Serve 0.8: A Self-Hostable Go-Powered Git Server ‚Äî Another handy project from the folks at Charm. Soft Serve is a self-hostable Git server that offers up a nice terminal UI (TUI) over SSH, has various access control features for collaborative use cases, and even supports Git¬†LFS.

Charm

‚öôÔ∏è¬†Orchestrion: Compile-Time Auto-Instrumentation for Go ‚Äî Instrumenting code is tedious and inconsistent when done manually, but automating it is difficult. Enter Orchestrion, which injects instrumentation at compile-time and supports many third-party libraries so you can instrument your code, create tracers, etc. without changing the dev¬†process.

Datadog Team

Zero Ops Apache Kafka Replication and Data Mirroring ‚Äî Moving to WarpStream to reduce your Kafka costs by 80+% and simplify ops is easy with 1:1 replication provided by¬†Orbit.

WarpStream sponsor

go-wasm-http-server 2.0: Embed Go HTTP Handlers in a Service Worker ‚Äî Embed your Go HTTP handlers in a Service Worker using WebAssembly and emulate an HTTP server browser-side. Some of the examples might give you some¬†inspiration.

Nicolas Lepage

Goverter: A Type-Safe Go Converter Generator ‚Äî Generate type-safe converters by writing signatures of the type conversions and then Goverter will write the code you need to make it happen. GitHub¬†repo.

Jannis Mattheis

Echo: Extensible, Minimalist Go Web Framework ‚Äî Though it‚Äôs not too minimal, offering HTTP routing, automatic TLS, data binding, templating, middleware, and different ways to render data out of the box. v4.13.0 removes the JWT middleware from Echo core due to security issues. GitHub¬†repo.

LabStack LLC

GTML: Make Writing HTML in Go a Breeze ‚Äî This package touts itself with ‚ÄúThink of it like JSX for Go,‚Äù allowing you to take an HTML-like syntax and generate a StringBuilder that renders it in Go¬†code.

Phillip England

üì∞¬†Classifieds

How Authorization fits into the Architecture of Secure AI RAG stacks? Watch AuthZed CEO Jacob Moshenko addressing this topic, and more with The¬†Cube.

üì¨ Hookdeck: A serverless queue to reliably send, receive, transform, filter, and route events across your event-driven¬†apps.

üëã Tired of failures and outages? Let Temporal keep your code running flawlessly. Start on Temporal Cloud with $1,000 in free¬†credits.

gARM: An ARM64 Compiler for Go ‚Äî The author thinks we can do better than Go‚Äôs assembly approach for high performance ARM64 use cases, so has set out to make his own approach. It's early days, however.

Sven Woldt

  • golang-set 2.7 ‚Äì Robust generic set¬†type. Now supports proper JSON marshalling/unmarshalling without¬†workarounds.

  • FastHTTP 1.58 ‚Äì Performance-oriented alternative to net/http for specific¬†scenarios.

  • ü§ñ go-pot 1.0 ‚Äì A Go 'HTTP tarpit' designed to 'maximize bot¬†misery.'

  • üîí Fibratus 2.3 ‚Äì 'Adversary tradecraft detection' tool for MS¬†Windows.

  • Mockery 2.50 ‚Äì Generate mocks for¬†interfaces.

  • webdav 5.5 ‚Äì Standalone WebDAV¬†server.

item.title: „ÄêA look back at Go's 2024„ÄëÂõûÈ°æ Go ÁöÑ 2024 Âπ¥
item.description:
„Äê

#‚Äã536 ‚Äî December 17, 2024

Unsub¬†¬†|¬†¬†Web¬†Version

üéÑ A mixed bag this week as we cover a few news items but then get into a 2024 roundup of Go news and the most clicked items of the year, in case you missed them at the time.

We're taking a Christmas break for two weeks and will be back on January 8, 2025, so we hope you have a Merry Christmas and a Happy New Year!
__
Peter Cooper and the Cooperpress team

Go Weekly

Go 1.24 Release Candidate 1 Released ‚Äî This announcement isn‚Äôt particularly exciting, but if you want to get ahead of what‚Äôs coming in February 2025 with the final Go 1.24 release, the holidays aren't a bad time to have a play. The draft Go 1.24 release notes go into more¬†detail.

Carlos and Michael (Go Team)

üí° 'Go 1.24 is Looking Seriously Awesome' gives a more blog-style rundown of some feature¬†highlights.

Go Protobuf and the New Opaque API ‚Äî The existing protobuf module is here to stay, but now we get an additional API that provides a more loosely coupled abstraction for working with protobufs without being tied to their underlying in-memory representations. The benefits? Memory efficiency, lazy decoding, and fewer opportunities for¬†bugs.

Michael Stapelberg

Go Beyond Limits with Golang, Rust, Docker¬†&¬†K8s ‚Äî Struggling with tech challenges? Ardan Labs offers unparalleled consulting in Go, Rust, Docker, and Kubernetes. Enhance your development speed, optimize your architecture, and manage tech debt. Propel your team to new heights with our¬†expertise!

Ardan Labs Consulting sponsor

Benchmarking Different Go SQLite Drivers (Again) ‚Äî An update of a benchmark we first linked a year ago. As with any benchmark results, maintain a critical eye here, but the author found significant differences between the now eight options (previously¬†seven).

Christoph Vilsmeier

QUICK RELEASES:

  • GoReleaser v2.5 ‚Äì The popular tool to build and distribute Go programs for multiple platforms now supports Rust and Zig¬†too.

  • easyjson 0.8 ‚Äì Marshal/unmarshal structs to/from JSON sans¬†reflection.

  • Chi 5.2 ‚Äì Composable router for Go HTTP¬†services.

  • gopls v0.17 ‚Äì Official Go language server.

ü•á Top Go Developments and Items of 2024

2024 was, as always, a good year for Go, but there were some highlights:

  • Go 1.22 was released back in February with its enhanced HTTP routing approach, for loop ranging over integers, loop variable semantics changes, and the new math/rand/v2 package.

  • Also in February, Go entered the top 10 of the TIOBE language popularity index reaching #8. It currently sits at¬†#7.

  • Go 1.23 was released six months later in August. We called it a 'major minor' release as it was a gentle step forward, but with some noteworthy features like range over function types and the mildly controversial opt-in telemetry.

  • Russ Cox stepped down as tech lead of Go in September. He went on to speak more about this in this Go Time podcast¬†episode.

  • In November, Go turned 15 years old.

WorkOS: Sell to Enterprises with a Few Lines of Code ‚Äî The modern identity platform for B2B SaaS, offering flexible, easy-to-use APIs to integrate SSO, SCIM, and FGA in minutes instead of¬†months.

WorkOS sponsor

Next, what did you click on most this year? Let's find out!

1.¬†Cogent Core: A New GUI Framework for Go ‚Äî I was surprised this was by far the most clicked link as news tends to trump frameworks/libraries. Cogent is a ‚Äúcode once, run everywhere‚Äù GUI framework aiming to be simpler than Gio and more powerful than Fyne. Cogent‚Äôs site itself is built with the framework and compiled to WASM to run on the Web. It remains under active¬†development.

Kai O'Reilly and Randy O'Reilly

2.¬†What's Coming in Go 1.24 ‚Äî A very recent post with a slide deck teasing what's coming in Go 1.24 early next year. It goes through language, tooling, and standard library changes and some of the more experimental parts. The video of this talk still remains to be released,¬†sadly.

Daniel Mart√≠

3.¬†Interactive Release Notes for Go 1.23 ‚Äî If you find traditional release notes hard going, this interactive alternative with inline executable code snippets might help you get a grip on 1.23, still the latest major version of Go. Anton also had a similar set of notes for Go¬†1.22.

Anton Zhiyanov

4.¬†Rust vs Go in 2024? ‚Äî A perennially popular post from yesteryear was tweaked for 2024 with a comparison of the ‚Äòboth awesome‚Äô languages including what they‚Äôre both good at, their key differences, and some trade-offs to¬†consider. More recently, however, John has asserted that Rust and Go are better off together than¬†apart.

John Arundel

5.¬†Learning Go in 2024; From Beginner to Senior ‚Äî Matt brought together six years of bookmarks (and YouTube history) to point to something for everyone hoping to pick up some new Go skills in¬†2024.

Matt Boyle

6.¬†Why People are 'Angry' Over Go 1.23 Iterators ‚Äî ‚ÄòAngry‚Äô is a little OTT, but there was much robust debate about Go‚Äôs proposed new iterator helpers earlier this year. The creator of the Odin language chimed in with his thoughts, opining that Go should stay unapologetically¬†imperative.

Ginger Bill

7.¬†Gomponents 1.0: HTML View Components in Pure Go ‚Äî We first linked to this back in 2020, and it‚Äôs not only still going strong, it hit v1.0 this year. Now a stable, dependency-free HTML component library for your Go projects (there‚Äôs also an example app to look¬†through).

Markus W√ºstenberg

8.¬†Go Performance from Version 1.0 to 1.22 ‚Äî Two years ago we enjoyed the author‚Äôs Go performance analysis from Go 1.2 to 1.18. This was an update taking things from Go 1.0 through to 1.22 (the latest version back in¬†April).

Ben Hoyt

üì∞¬†Classifieds

What has happened this year in the world of Authorization? Check out Authorization 2024 Year in Review.

Hookdeck: An alternative to Amazon API Gateway + Lambda + SQS. With local dev, debugging, and observability built-in.
